title: 104_hr1684
content: The "Dolley Madison Commemorative Coin Act" authorizes the minting of 500,000 $1 silver coins to commemorate the 150th anniversary of Dolley Madison's death. The coins will weigh 26.73 grams, have a diameter of 1.500 inches, and contain 90% silver and 10% copper. They will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The Secretary will only obtain silver for minting coins from stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. The design of the coins will be determined under this Act. The design of the coins minted under this Act shall commemorate the 150th anniversary of Dolley Madison's death and the achievements of the wife of the 4th President of the United States. Each coin will feature a value designation, the year "1999", and inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with Montpelier, the National Trust for Historic Preservation, and the Commission of Fine Arts. The design of the coins minted under this Act commemorates the 150th anniversary of Dolley Madison's death and the achievements of the wife of the 4th President of the United States. The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with Montpelier, the National Trust for Historic Preservation, the Commission of Fine Arts, and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act shall be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at a designated Mint facility starting January 1, 1999, with minting authority ending on December 31, 1999. The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value of the coins, a surcharge of $10 per coin, and the cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount on sale prices. SEC. 7. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS. No procurement laws apply to goods and services needed for this Act, except for equal employment opportunity laws. SEC. 8. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. Surcharges from coin sales will be paid to the National Trust for Historic Preservation for Montpelier's endowment and restoration projects. SEC. 9. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. SEC. 9. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary must ensure no net cost to the Government for minting coins. Payment for coins requires full payment, security, or a guarantee of payment from a depository institution. Payment of Surcharges: No surcharge proceeds from coin sales shall be paid to the National Trust until all numismatic costs are recovered and the Trust raises equal or more funds from private sources. Annual audits are required. Annual audits are required for recipients of surcharge proceeds from coin sales, conducted by an independent public accountant selected by the National Trust. The audits must follow government auditing standards and continue until all surcharge amounts are fully expended or placed in trust. The National Trust must undergo annual audits to report the amount of payments received and expended from surcharges on coin sales, ensuring all expenditures were for authorized purposes. The National Trust must ensure that payments from surcharges on coin sales are accounted for separately and submit an audit report to the Secretary of the Treasury within 90 days after the end of each fiscal year. The National Trust must provide a copy of the audit report to the public and can use surcharge proceeds to cover audit costs. The Secretary of the Treasury has the authority to waive subsection requirements based on surcharge amounts received or spent. The National Trust must make books and records available to receive surcharge payments. The National Trust must provide audit reports to the public and can use surcharge proceeds for audit costs. Books, records, and workpapers must be provided to the Inspector General or Comptroller General upon request. No surcharge funds can be used to compensate agents or attorneys for influencing coin legislation. National Trust will compensate agents or attorneys for influencing legislative action on coins minted under this Act. The House of Representatives passed the legislation on September 17, 1996.
